Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History Digitization of Arctic and Sub-Arctic Marine Invertebrate Collections of the University of Alaska Museum
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Alaska Museum (UAM) to generate and publish electronic records from over 9,000 collections of marine invertebrates currently archived at the museum. These collections represent the results of oceanographic research on the faunal diversity of Arctic and sub-Arctic oceans over a period spanning five decades. The expertly curated, digitized records will be available to the global community of researchers interested in marine ecology for study. Understanding the diversity and patterns of distribution of Arctic and sub-Arctic marine faunas is of special urgency given growing interest in the development of mineral resources and transportation routes in those waters.

Additionally, in the process of ensuring the preservation and dissemination of the information associated with the marine invertebrate collections at UAM, the project will promote training and improve expertise in taxonomy and biodiversity research. A graduate student will receive training on natural history collections research and on invertebrate taxonomy. Undergraduate students will work in the digitization effort and gain first hand experience with scientific research. All aspects of the project will also involve training, mentorship and the development of an appreciation of the importance of collections-based research. Data records from the UAM will be readily accessible through the Arctos database web portal located at http://arctos.database.museum/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The number and preservation conditions of marine invertebrate research specimens at the University of Alaska Museum (UAM) were significantly increased and improved through the curation and digitization efforts supported by this project. At the start of the project, approximately 9,000 samples of Arctic and sub-Arctic marine invertebrates holding valuable information linked to their anatomy, and time and place of collection were not available to the research community because they were not included in the museum's electronic catalogs. Further, the preservation conditions of those materials did not adhere to current best practices. The collection's database covered a little over one half of all the materials held at the museum and did not yet include important specimens such as those gathered during early research based in the Arctic coast of North America in the mid 1900's. The central objective of this project was to ensure best conditions of preservation and data availability for all these uncatalogued marine invertebrate collections. In addition, the effort included a substantial training component for students interested in biodiversity research.

The curation activities conducted as part of the project led directly to training and research experience for 15 undergraduate students and two graduate students. Undergraduate students learned how to prepare and preserve specimens of marine invertebrates from the most abundant and ecologically important lineages found in the Alaskan marine waters. The graduate students received training in the use and management of the Arctos database, an online collections data management system used by 140 research collections. While participating in the project, the graduate students developed and completed thesis research studies aiming to improve understanding of the population and species diversity of two marine invertebrate lineages with widespread Arctic and sub-Arctic distributions. Overall, the project provided valuable work experiences for students interested in biological research and in doing so, contributed to their career development.

The UAM marine invertebrates collection database now holds records from over 20,000 collection events, nearly doubling the amount of information it contained prior to this project. All the records in the Arctos database are available to the public and the research community through a feature-rich online search interface, and they are also publicly available through large biodiversity information portals, such as iDigBio and GBIF. Importantly, the specimens linked to the records added to the database now have upgraded storage and data tracking conditions to ensure that the value of the information they represent is maintained over the long term. In summary, the project resulted in a dramatic improvement to the only existing marine invertebrate research collection in Alaska and a substantial increase in the amount of information available to the marine invertebrate research community. The improvement supported by this effort has made the UAM collection a more valuable research resource to biologists interested in the diversity and ecology of Arctic marine invertebrates.
